title: Week 2: January 5–11 - Moses 1; Abraham 3
content:
# Come, Follow Me 2026: Week 2 - Moses 1; Abraham 3

## Theological Framework

What if the opening of the scriptures did not begin with creation, but with a prophet's plea for divine identity? This mystery unfolds in Moses 1, where the Lord's response frames all that follows: “Be merciful unto thy servant, O God, and tell me concerning this earth, and the inhabitants thereof, and also the heavens” (Moses 1:36). Here, doctrinal themes of divine identity, purpose, and eternal progression emerge as a pattern mastery across dispensations—from Moses's vision to Abraham's premortal revelations.

**Pattern Recognition Mastery**: Consider the identical principle of divine sonship. God declares to Moses, "thou art my son" (Moses 1:4, 6), echoing the premortal council where noble spirits, including Abraham, were organized "before the world was" (Abraham 3:22–28). This mirrors the foundational truth President Russell M. Nelson taught: “If the Lord were speaking to you directly, the first thing He would make sure you understand is your true identity” (“Choices for Eternity” [worldwide devotional for young adults, May 2022], Gospel Library). From Adam's dispensation onward, God reveals humanity's premortal nobility to empower eternal choices, as seen in Abraham 3:22–23 where spirits are "organized before they were natural" for proving through earthly probation. This pattern indicates God's consistent work: to exalt His children through Christ, culminating in Moses 1:39 where the Lord proclaims His "work and my glory" as bringing "to pass the immortality and eternal life of man."

## Language and Literary Insights

The literary structure of Moses 1 builds dramatic tension through direct dialogue, contrasting God's affirming voice with Satan's deceitful one. God's words form a chiastic pattern: identity declaration (Moses 1:4, 6), vision of worlds (1:27–39), purpose revelation. Satan interrupts with counterfeits (Moses 1:12), but Moses's refrain—"Get thee hence, Satan" (Moses 1:13, 15, 18)—escalates to triumph via the Lord's power (1:20–26). Abraham 3 employs visionary ascent, layering premortal truths: spirits "make an earth" and "prove" themselves (Abraham 3:22–28), creating paradigm shifts from mere creation narratives to purposeful probation.

This structure reveals hidden connections: Moses 1:36's inquiry propels both chapters, answering "why these things are so" (Moses 1:30) with premortal organization (Abraham 3:24–26). Such literary parallelism invites readers to see Genesis anew through latter-day light.

## Prophetic Patterns Across Time

Divine patterns of revelation follow a repeatable template: vision of glory, satanic opposition, covenant purpose. Moses beholds God's creations (Moses 1:27–39), resists Satan (1:12–26), learns his mission (1:6). Abraham ascends to see premortal intelligences (Abraham 3:22–28), converging with Moses's query on earth's inhabitants. This pattern spans prophets: both receive tailored visions post-personal crisis, emphasizing redemption through proving.

**Generational Pattern Mapping**: Ancient covenants link to modern discipleship. Abraham 3:25 urges spirits to "prove themselves" amid choices, paralleling Moses's resistance and today's call to prioritize divine identity amid Satan's confusion (Moses 1:12). Jesus Christ emerges as the One "one among the selves" (Abraham 3:22–23), the Redeemer bridging premortal choice to eternal life (Moses 1:39).

## Cross-Reference Web Matrix

Unseen relationships bind these chapters across standard works:

- **Identity Matrix**: Moses 1:4,6 ("thou art my son") → Abraham 3:22–23 (noble spirits) → Doctrine and Covenants 11:20 (God's work through servants).
- **Resistance Web**: Moses 1:12–26 (reject counterfeits) → Matthew 4:1–11 (Christ's temptation) → Gary E. Stevenson, “Deceive Me Not,” Ensign or Liahona, Nov. 2019, 93–96.
- **Purpose Nexus**: Moses 1:39 (immortality and eternal life) → Abraham 3:24–26 (probationary state) → Topics and Questions, “Eternal Life,” Gospel Library.
- **Premortal Threads**: Abraham 3:22–28 ("before the world was") → Topics and Questions, “Premortal Life,” Gospel Library.

These form a web where Moses's plea (1:36) illuminates Abraham's council, revealing Christ's role in all.

## Historical and Cultural Context

In an ancient world of polytheistic confusion, Moses 1 pierces the veil, showing one true God whose creations declare His glory (Moses 1:31–39). Abraham 3:22–28 unveils premortal existence, countering cultural myths of spontaneous origins with organized intelligences. This context creates "aha moments": earth's inhabitants are proven spirits (Abraham 3:25), paralleling modern discipleship where identity precedes labels. Pioneers echoed this, viewing trials as Abrahamic proving grounds, much as families today discuss resistance at mealtime (Teaching in the Savior’s Way, 31).

## Reconciling Difficult Passages

Why temptation after divine vision? Moses 1:12–26 reconciles this: spiritual highs invite satanic doubt, yet the Lord empowers overcoming (1:24–26). Apparent tension—God withdraws momentarily (1:20)—resolves as Moses relies on past testimony: "I know that man is nothing" yet "I am a son of God" (1:21, drawing from 1:4,6). Satan's worship demand (1:12) contrasts God's no-worship-needed glory (1:31–39), revealing counterfeits. Properly understood, this teaches enduring faith amid opposition.

## Deeper Study Notes

Advanced pattern discovery from these texts equips teachers for adult study. Map Moses's progression: declaration (1:4–6), vision (1:27–39), resistance (1:12–26). Overlay Abraham 3:22–28's premortal hierarchy: intelligences → organization → probation → exaltation. Note escalating commands to Satan (Moses 1:13,15,18,20–22,26), modeling invocation of Christ's name. Adapt for classes: chart "prove" choices (Abraham 3:25) against daily decisions, linking to For the Strength of Youth: A Guide for Making Choices.

## Teaching Applications

**Escalating Stakes Discussion Questions**:

1. **Understanding**: What differences emerge comparing God's words (Moses 1:4,6) and Satan's (1:12)? How does President Nelson's counsel—“The way you think about who you really are affects almost every decision you will ever make” (“Choices for Eternity”)—clarify this?
   
2. **Transformation**: List counterfeits in Moses 1:13–18; how can families act out resistance (1:13,15,18,20–22,26), like mirror affirmations ("I am a child of God," Moses 1:4)?

3. **Testimony**: How does Abraham 3:22–28's premortal truths change earthly choices? Practice responses to proving situations (3:25); what work has God for you (Moses 1:6; Doctrine and Covenants 11:20)?

Use Gospel Art Book nos. 13–16 or Old Testament Stories, pages 64–84, for visuals; sing “I Am a Child of God,” Hymns, no. 301.

## Modern Prophetic Convergence

Contemporary revelation mirrors ancient precisely. President Russell M. Nelson taught, “If the Lord were speaking to you directly, the first thing He would make sure you understand is your true identity” (“Choices for Eternity”), converging with Moses 1:4,6. He adds, “The way you think about who you really are affects almost every decision you will ever make” (“Choices for Eternity”), echoing Satan's identity assault (Moses 1:12) and premortal proving (Abraham 3:22–28). Read “First: Know the truth about who you are” in “Choices for Eternity” for deeper alignment.

## Testimony Development

Pattern recognition forges unshakeable conviction. Tracing divine sonship from Moses 1:4 through Abraham 3:22–28 to Nelson's words reveals God's unchanging voice amid chaos. Recognizing counterfeits (Moses 1:13–18) builds resilience; premortal truths (Abraham 3:24–26) anchor purpose. Deep study shows Christ's centrality—bringing immortality and eternal life (Moses 1:39)—igniting personal witness that we are His children, destined for glory.

I bear testimony that these revelations, pondered deeply, confirm our noble origin and divine potential.

## Additional Study

Explore bundle resources: “Our True Identity” (video), Gospel Library; “I Am a Son of God” (video), Gospel Library; Topics and Questions, “Children of God,” “Premortal Life,” “Eternal Life.” Liahona, For the Strength of Youth, Friend magazines this month. Videos: “I Will Follow God’s Plan” (Children’s Songbook, 164–65). Cross-reference Matthew 4:1–11; Gary E. Stevenson, “Deceive Me Not”; “Choices for Eternity” section on identity.
